subject: history
title: Simon Commission & Indian Response (1927-1930)
description: All-White Commission boycotted by Indians; 'Simon Go Back' movement

phases.name: Announcement & Arrival
phases.description: Commission announced and arrives; protests begin

phases.name: Report & Impact
phases.description: Commission's report published; irrelevant by then

events.title: Background: GOI Act 1919 Review Clause
events.description: Act required review after 10 years; Commission appointed 2 years early

points: Government of India Act 1919 contained provision for review after 10 years (by 1929)
Conservative government in Britain (Stanley Baldwin PM) feared Labour might come to power
Decided to appoint Commission 2 years early (1927) before Labour won
Labour Party more sympathetic to Indian demands
Conservatives wanted to control reform process

events.title: Simon Commission Announced
events.description: All-White commission to review Indian constitutional reforms

composition.chairman: Sir John Simon (Liberal lawyer and politician)

mandate: Review working of Government of India Act 1919
Recommend next steps in constitutional development
insult: No Indian member in commission to decide India's future
British deciding for Indians without Indian participation
Treated Indians as subjects incapable of self-governance

events.title: Immediate Indian Outrage
events.description: All parties unanimously condemn all-white commission

reactions: Congress: Immediate rejection; demanded Indian participation
Muslim League: Also rejected (Jinnah led opposition)
UNPRECEDENTED UNITY: All Indian political parties united in opposition
reasons: Indians capable of deciding own future
After sacrifice in WWI, still treated as inferiors
Dyarchy had failed; Indians knew why; didn't need British to tell them
details.slogan: 'All parties and all communities united in rejection'

events.title: Madras Congress Session - Boycott Decided
events.description: Congress decides to boycott Commission at all stages

decision: Resolution: Complete boycott of Simon Commission
No meetings, no evidence, no assistance
Black flag demonstrations when Commission arrives
opposition: Jinnah initially wanted cooperation if Indians included

events.title: Simon Commission Arrives in India (Bombay)
events.description: Greeted with black flags and 'Simon Go Back' slogans

details.scale: Unprecedented nationwide protest; unity of all communities

events.title: Lahore Protest - Lala Lajpat Rai Lathi Charge
events.description: Brutal police lathi charge on peaceful protest; Lajpat Rai injured

event: Massive procession led by Lala Lajpat Rai to protest
Police Superintendent James Scott ordered lathi charge
Brutal lathi charge on peaceful protesters
Lala Lajpat Rai (Punjab Kesari, 63 years old) beaten severely on chest
Lajpat Rai injured but continued leading protest
details.lajpatStatement: Lajpat Rai declared: 'Every blow aimed at me is a nail in the coffin of British imperialism'
details.aftermath: Lajpat Rai died 17 days later (November 17, 1928); injuries likely contributed though exact cause disputed

events.title: Death of Lala Lajpat Rai
events.description: Punjab Kesari dies; nation mourns; rage against British

death: Died November 17, 1928 (17 days after lathi charge)
Popular belief: injuries from lathi charge contributed
Became martyr; funeral attended by lakhs
impact: Demand for revenge (led to Saunders' assassination by Bhagat Singh, Rajguru, Sukhdev)
details.legacy: 'Punjab Kesari' (Lion of Punjab) remembered as martyr who died protesting British tyranny

events.title: Lucknow Protest - Jawaharlal Nehru Injured
events.description: Police brutality on protesters; Nehru and others injured

event: Protest led by Jawaharlal Nehru and others
Govind Ballabh Pant seriously injured (permanent damage to health)
details.significance: Showed British willing to use violence against peaceful protesters; further alienated Indians

events.title: Calcutta and Other Cities - Continued Protests

pattern: Commission toured India city by city
Everywhere: Black flags, hartals, 'Simon Go Back' slogans
By April 1929, Commission completed hearings and left India
participation: Students, workers, professionals, women - all sections participated
Even some princes expressed discontent privately

events.title: Indian Alternative Proposals Emerge
events.description: Indians decide to draft own constitution

logic: If British won't include Indians in Simon Commission,
Indians will draft own constitutional proposal
Show British that Indians capable of self-governance
initiatives: Task: Draft constitution acceptable to all Indian parties

events.title: Simon Commission Report Published
events.description: Report published but ignored by Indians; irrelevant

timing: Report published June 1930 (2 years after arrival)
By then, political situation completely changed
Indians not interested in Simon Report
recommendations: Abolish dyarchy; introduce 'responsible government' in provinces
Centre remain under British control (defence, foreign policy)
Gradual reforms; no immediate dominion status
reception: Engaged in Civil Disobedience; beyond reforms
Demand shifted to Purna Swaraj (complete independence)
outcome: Recommendations formed basis for Government of India Act 1935
But by then, Indians wanted much more
Simon Commission fiasco showed British out of touch with Indian aspirations

assessment.title: Significance & Impact of Simon Commission

britishPerspective: Commission boycotted completely; couldn't gather adequate Indian opinion
Showed Indians united against British policies

indianPerspective: Congress, Muslim League, Hindu Mahasabha, Liberals - all boycotted together
Mass mobilization practice for future movements
Lala Lajpat Rai became martyr; inspired revolutionaries (Bhagat Singh)
Forced Indians to draft own constitution (Nehru Report)
Demonstrated Indians' political maturity and unity
Shifted demand from reforms to complete independence

keyOutcomes: Government of India Act 1935 (partially based on Simon Report)
legacy: 'Simon Go Back' became symbol of Indian resistance
Lala Lajpat Rai's martyrdom inspired generation
Proved British couldn't impose reforms without Indian consultation
Last time British tried to exclude Indians from constitutional process

mustRemember: Lala Lajpat Rai beaten in Lahore protest (Oct 30, 1928); died Nov 17, 1928
Unanimously boycotted by all Indian parties
Report published June 1930; ignored by Indians
Led to Nehru Report (1928), Jinnah's 14 Points, Purna Swaraj (1929)
